title: Rape and Sexual Assault in IPV Context
description: Understanding how sexual violence functions as a tool of power and control in intimate partner relationships and how to support survivors.

content.narration: We reach the deepest part of the twilight zone, where sexual violence and intimate partner violence converge. This intersection reveals uncomfortable truths—marital rape wasn't criminalized in all states until 1993, and intimate partner sexual violence remains deeply underreported. Understanding these hidden depths prepares you to provide truly trauma-informed support.

sections.title: The Intersection of IPV and Sexual Violence
sections.content:
## Rape and Sexual Assault in the Context of Intimate Partner Violence

Most sexual assault is committed by someone the survivor knows. This is often referred to as **acquaintance rape**, but if you were asked to name an acquaintance, you might think of a classmate, a coworker, or a friend—not someone with whom you're in a long-term relationship or someone to whom you are married.

**According to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence:**

- It's estimated that between **10% and 14%** of married women will be raped at some point during their marriages
- Marital rape is the **most underreported** form of sexual assault

### The Reality of Intimate Partner Sexual Violence

Intimate partner violence can include sexual assault. This can be both surprising and confusing to the public and even to individuals new to working with survivors. In fact, this concept is still presented as shocking news in popular culture and media.

**The truth is that intimate partner sexual assault:**

- Happens to people of all races, genders, ages, social classes, ethnicities, and abilities
- Occurs when the person causing harm uses sexual assault or rape as a means of exerting control over the survivor
- Is used to intimidate, control, and demean survivors of domestic violence

### Prevalence

Intimate partner sexual violence is far more common than you might think:

- Between **40% and 45%** of women in abusive relationships will also be sexually assaulted during the course of the relationship
- Only **36%** of all rape survivors ever report the crime to the police
- The percentage of married women who report a spousal rape to the police is even lower
- Women who are sexually abused by intimate partners report **more risk factors for intimate partner homicides** than non-sexually abused women

sections.title: Sexual Violence and the Power and Control Wheel
sections.content:
## Using Intimate Partner Sexual Violence for Power and Control

When intimate partner sexual violence is present in an abusive relationship, it is often used alongside other types of abuse on the Power and Control Wheel. It can be physical, visual, or verbal, and take place individually or in any combination.

### How Sexual Violence Manifests Across the Wheel

**On the Outer Ring (Physical and Sexual Violence):**
- Forced sexual contact
- Rape and sexual assault
- Physical violence during or related to sex

**Connected to Inner Sections:**

- **Using Intimidation:** Threatening sexual violence; making them afraid through sexual gestures or actions
- **Using Emotional Abuse:** Calling them sexually degrading names; making them feel sexually inadequate
- **Using Isolation:** Controlling their sexuality; preventing them from seeing friends who might notice abuse
- **Minimizing/Denying/Blaming:** Saying the sexual assault didn't happen; claiming they wanted it; blaming them for "causing" it
- **Using Coercion and Threats:** Threatening to rape them; threatening to be unfaithful; pressuring for unwanted sexual acts

### The Punishment Dynamic

In other words, if the survivor doesn't respond to the threats, abusive behaviors, or emotional abuse in a way that makes the person causing harm feel empowered or in control, the abuser may see sexual assault as a punishment for the survivor.

The way this threat is communicated can vary:
- Explicit graphic explanations of what the abuser intends to do
- Implied threats paired with other behaviors
- Part of a larger pattern of control and coercion

sections.title: Barriers and Support
sections.content:
## Barriers to Identifying Intimate Partner Sexual Violence

Intimate partner sexual violence carries many of the same impacts as domestic violence and sexual violence individually, but also has a number of unique challenges that can impact survivors.

### Common Barriers:

**Conceptual Barriers:**
- The survivor may view sex as a "spousal duty"
- Assuming that being in a relationship means passive consent to all future sex
- This intersection of rape and sex can cause survivors to classify their experience as "sex" instead of "violence"
- Difficulty reconciling love for the partner with the harm the partner has caused
- Hesitance to define someone they love as a "rapist"

**Legal and Social Barriers:**
- Until 1976, state laws specifically **exempted spousal rape** from general rape laws
- It wasn't until **1993** that all fifty states had repealed their spousal rape exemptions
- Many states still continued to treat marital rape differently than non-marital rape
- Even now, some states legally consider marital rape as a lesser crime than non-marital rape

### Supporting Survivors

When engaging with a survivor of sexual assault who has chosen to disclose their experience to you, it is a signal that they believe you can be trusted.

**Critical Response Elements:**

- **Listen to them** without judgment
- **Continue to build trust** through your actions and words
- **Maintain an environment of safety and confidentiality**
- There may be several reasons they are uncomfortable disclosing full details—and that's okay
- If you provide an environment where they feel safe, heard, and believed, survivors are more likely to share their experiences and be receptive to recommendations for support and services

### Survivor Reactions

There is no right way for a survivor to react to being sexually assaulted by their partner. Some common reactions include:

- Fear they won't be believed
- Wondering if it's their fault
- Feeling alone or not sure who they can talk to
- PTSD symptoms (dissociation, flashbacks, nightmares)
- Feeling emotionally numb and detached from other people
- Difficulty remembering aspects of the event
- Increased use of alcohol and/or illicit drugs
- Self-harm

A survivor's response to their experience can impact how and when they may disclose sexual assault, if at all. People who cause harm often know this and may use these reactions or feelings to further the abuse—using insults, demeaning language, or threats to make the survivor feel ashamed and keep them isolated from support systems.

keyTakeaways: Between 40-45% of women in abusive relationships are also sexually assaulted during the relationship
Marital rape is the most underreported form of sexual assault and wasn't criminalized in all states until 1993
Intimate partner sexual violence is used as a tool of power and control, often alongside other abusive tactics
Survivors face unique barriers including conceptual difficulties (viewing sex as 'spousal duty') and legal/social challenges
When a survivor discloses to you, they're signaling trust—respond with belief, safety, and confidentiality
Women sexually abused by intimate partners report more risk factors for intimate partner homicide

activities.title: Prevalence and Underreporting
activities.prompt: What percentage of women in abusive relationships are also sexually assaulted during the course of the relationship?
activities.explanation: Between 40% AND 45% of women in abusive relationships will also be sexually assaulted during the course of the relationship. This high percentage demonstrates how commonly sexual violence is used as a tool of power and control in abusive relationships. Despite this prevalence, intimate partner sexual violence remains deeply underreported, with marital rape being the most underreported form of sexual assault.

activities.title: Legal History
activities.prompt: When did all fifty states finally repeal their spousal rape exemptions?
activities.explanation: It wasn't until 1993 that all fifty states had repealed their spousal rape exemptions. Until 1976, state laws specifically EXEMPTED spousal rape from general rape laws—meaning it was legal for a husband to rape his wife. Even after 1993, many states continued to treat marital rape differently than non-marital rape. Understanding this recent legal history helps explain why intimate partner sexual violence is so underreported and why survivors face unique barriers.

activities.title: Trauma-Informed Response
activities.prompt: When a survivor of intimate partner sexual violence discloses to you, what is the MOST important response?
options: Immediately report it to law enforcement
Ask detailed questions to verify their story
Listen without judgment and create an environment of safety, trust, and confidentiality
Tell them they need to leave the relationship immediately
activities.explanation: The MOST important response is to LISTEN without judgment and CREATE AN ENVIRONMENT OF SAFETY, TRUST, AND CONFIDENTIALITY. When a survivor discloses, it signals they believe you can be trusted. If you provide an environment where they feel safe, heard, and believed, they're more likely to share their experiences and be receptive to support. Your role is not to investigate, force reporting, or make decisions for them—it's to provide trauma-informed support that honors their autonomy.
